loans.name: Winifred Neba

texts.en:
Born in 1968, Winifred is married and mother of five children, all in school. The passing away of her supportive father and brother within one year, coupled with continuous difficulties to raise capital, caused her to take a friend’s advice to take a loan. On completion of the Minimum Skills Workshop organized by GHAPE for first-time borrowers, she received her first loan in 2003. Her performance earned trust and she was later elected to a leadership position, Centre Chief of her center. With previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with good quality raw foodstuff. She is proud of having contributed financially in paying school fees for her children.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to increase her stock by buying beans, garri and potatoes. She is convinced that her business will succeed because of her marketing skills, the available market provided by the ever increasing population of the Bamenda urban center, her business site, and the availability and advantages of liquidity. She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Trading

loans.name: Celine

texts.en:
Born in 1975, Celine is in a polygamous marriage and mother of three children. After the death of her two children and her mother within a space of two months, and the costly procedure at the birth of her last child, Celine needed a strong support system to deal with her loss and economic issues.

She saw GHAPE as the only shoulder to lean on. Her group and center has continued to provide her with support as they share their experience. With acquired minimum marketing and management skills, she utilized and repaid her first two loans. Her goal for her next loan is to regain self-esteem through interactions and more business techniques.

With a loan of $300, she plans to increase her stock by buying raw foodstuff and fruits in bulk. The growing population of Mbemgwi, her skills and commitment in improving her situation, and the location of her business are factors indicating success. She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Trading and farming.

loans.name: Ambe Anna

texts.en:
Born in 1974, Anna has custody of her four children and the six children of her two late brothers. After separating from her husband, it was out of necessity that Anna had to engage in income-generating activities. In her desperation, her neighbor encouraged her to join GHAPE. With peer support and management skills acquired she succeeded in managing her previous loans. She is proud of having provided food to her community continuously.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to increase her stock by buying 240-liters of palm oil, 2 bags of koki beans, and second-hand dresses and bed-sheets. She will bring these items closer to members of her community. She plans to get her children involved for two reasons: to assist her and to stay out of trouble. She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Trading

loans.name: Absalon

texts.en:
Absalon has worked in the production and sales of frames and mirrors for 8 years. He began learning the trade from another person 20 years ago. Upon his release from his work with that person he decided to frame a print of a painting and offer it for sale. He sold it to a friend. This moved him to open his own business. Using his savings, and a loan, he was able to rent a space where he began to buy printed works, mount them and then sell the framed paintings. His business grew to the point that he had as many as six people working for him, selling the frames that he created. Unfortunately, competition came to the area. He began manufacturing mirrors, which worked out well for him. Currently, he produces both products without any help, aside from his son who now paints frames. He works seven days a week from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. His shop is located in his home.

Absalon would like to obtain a loan to invest in the production of mirrors which he has stopped making due to his lack of funds.

Absalon is married. He is 40 years old and has 4 children, one of which has begun to assist him in the production of the painting frames. His wife works as a homemaker. With the investment, he would like to once again engage salesman, allowing him to better his business.

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

Absalon tiene una experiencia de 8 años en el negocio de fabricación y venta de cuadros y espejos, actividad que la aprendió por medio de una persona desde hace 20 años. Una vez que se abrió de dicha persona para la que trabajaba decide elaborar un cuadro y salirlo a vender el que se lo vendió a un amigo. Esto lo impulso a tener ya su negocio propio. Con los ahorros que tenia y un crédito logra alquilar un local donde comienza la elaboración de cuadros. Llego a tener hasta seis personas a su cargo que eran los que les vendían los cuadros que el elaboraba. Lamentablemente llego la competencia por lo que decide elaborar espejos con los que le fue muy bien. Al momento elabora los dos productos pero sin ayudantes, solo su hijo que ya pinta los cuadros. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 8 p.m. Tiene el taller ubicado en su domicilio.

Absalon desea el crédito para poder invertir en la elaboración de espejos los cuales ha dejado de fabricar por falta de capital.

Absalon es casado. Tiene 40 años y 4 hijos de los cuales uno ya le ayuda en la elaboración de sus cuadros. Su esposa se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar. Su deseo es poder con la inversión que hace lograr incluir nuevamente a vendedores que le ayuden a mejorar su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of materials and equipment to begin producing mirrors again.

loans.name: Mirabel Manka

texts.en:
Born in 1986, Mirabel is a mother of two, having had her first child at fourteen when she dropped out of school for lack of sponsorship. Married to a man who is also a struggler, she took her first loan in 2003 and started a koki business then later on started second-hand clothes selling, which her husband was very supportive of.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to buy in bales and sell in bulk to traders with limited capital, and continue to retail in flea markets. Her husband is determined to support her in selling some of the dresses in neighboring villages. She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Trading

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Born in 1963, Margaret is married and has six children. Five of her children are in school while her oldest daughter is already married. Memories of times her children have been sent home from school for not paying fees, and nights and days she watches her children with a temperature but cannot take them to hospital, are the sources of her motivation. Encouraged by other GHAPE members in her community she took her first loan in 2004. Her dream is to see her children independent.

Margaret is a third-time borrower. Given a loan of $300 she plans to increase her stock by buying gari (fried ground cassava), setting aside transport fare, and buying pig feed. She plan to repay her loan with income from the gari activity and will use the monies from the sale of her pigs in September for paying her children’s fees.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling of gari and rearing pigs

loans.name: Esther Manjoh

texts.en:
Born in 1972, Esther is a mother of five children. The death of her sister increased her parenting responsibility to nine children, and the often ill-health of her children is her motivation to become economically empowered. Esther is a fourth-time borrower. Her three previous loans provided her community with water-fu-fu (This is ground cassava prepared as thick porridge eaten with different types of soup. The favorite in this area is “water-fu-fu & erru”.) This gained her the name “Mami water-fu-fu”.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to maintain leadership in the supply of "water-fu-fu" in her quarter, stock in new items of "equsi" and cooking oil. Her long time goal is to own a restaurant and help others in need.

She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Producing water-fu-fu

loans.name: Festus Che

texts.en:
Born in 1967, Festus is married and father of two boys and one girl. He has not forgotten when thieves visited him and when the Urban Council confiscated vehicles from his garage at a time he was greatly struggling to build it with loans from GHAPE. However, he decided to forge ahead in the belief that obstacles will always be there but life has to continue. Festus is a fourth-time borrower. From his three previous loans he provided mechanic services to car owners in his community. He is proud of owning a functioning garage.

Given a loan of $800, he plans to buy old cars and spare parts and service some of the old cars in his garage. He is convinced that he will succeed because of lessons from the past, the quality of his work, and the ever-increasing customers resulting from the bad roads. His dream is to expand his garage and provide apprenticeships to other young people.

He plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Buying old cars and spare parts

loans.name: Alice Fonjong

texts.en:
Alice is a mother of seven children. She has to work daily to provide medication to her child who is suffering with epilepsy and is almost rejected by society. Being there for her child is her motivation to work even harder. She took her first loan in 2005 and succeeded in providing her community with fresh raw food.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to buy piglets, 20 bags of feed, sticks, and nails to repair and expand her pig fence and pay for vet services for the pigs. She plans to repay her loan from sales of manure, vegetable and empty bags of feed. She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Pig Farming

loans.name: Che

texts.en:
B. is a mother of five children. Though very disappointed when her husband sold her crop farm without her knowledge and the whole family suffered from hunger, she chose to make it work. She joined GHAPE and took her first loan and started Buyam-sellam of huckleberry. With this she provided her community with vegetables and minimally provided for the needs of her family. Later she diversified her activities; she bought a pig and start crop cultivation. Unable to pay school fees and buy books, she decided to pay apprenticeship fees for some of her children to learn vocational skills.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to rent a piece of land to farm, buy seeds and sticks to repair her pig fence, and to continue country-nja-ma-jama (huckleberry) activity. She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Pig and Crop Farming

loans.name: Gabriel Mbah

texts.en:
Gabriel has two wives and five children. After relocating to settle in his native village, he faced great challenges in providing for his family. This motivated him to join GHAPE and go through all the identified necessary trainings, which included marketing techniques and management organized by GHAPE and sister organizations. With a previous loan he succeeded in providing electronics and wiring services to his community.

Given a loan of $400, he plans to buy electronic spare parts, electrical materials and watch spare parts to continue with repair services and to sell equipment to technician at urban center prices. He plans to pay his loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Electronics repairs and household electricity wiring

loans.name: Nkemchob Esther

texts.en:
Born in 1960, Nkemchob is one of two wives with six children. The heavy school demands made daily by her children obliged her to start income-generation activities. She is a third-time borrower, having taken her first loan of $40 in 2003. With previous loans she succeeded in providing fast food, firewood, and corn to her community. Her immediate goal is to continue to contribute towards the education of their children.

With her experience in “buyam-sellam”, given a loan of $300, she plans to increase her stock by buying palm oil, firewood, and corn. With increased stock she will become a major supplier in her immediate community. She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Selling of firewood, palm oil, and corn

loans.name: Mary Afor

texts.en:
Born in 1970, Mary is married and has four children. The pain of seeing her children sent away from school for lack of books or school fees, and the absence of formal credit facilities, motivated her, as she puts it, to “take advantage of the services provided by GHAPE at my door steps”. She is a third-time borrower. With her two previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with cooked food. She is proud of having repaid her previous loans and acquired skills in credit management.

Given a loan of $200, she plans to buy pots, cups, plats, spoons and country fowls. Her location will provide her with a comparative advantage in providing cooked food to her immediate community. Her immediate goals are to build skills to manage bigger loans and to provide for her family.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling cooked food

loans.name: Loh

texts.en:
Loh is married and mother of six children. Coming from a Moslem background, it was difficult for her to join a group. Her inability to raise capital for business was the source of her motivation. She received training on marketing techniques and credit management from GHAPE. With her first loan of $40 she succeeded in providing her community with raw foodstuff and roasted corn, plantain and cocoyams.

With a loan of $200, she plans to continue in the same trade but increase stock by buying more charcoal, plantain, cocoyam and corn. She plans to pay her loan in 15 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the first month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Mobile Koki restaurant

loans.name: Lem Jennet

texts.en:
Lem, popularly called Mama Koki, was born in 1968. She is married and has four children. Her major goal is to work hand-in-hand with her husband to get all her children through school. She has received training in marketing techniques, credit and other survival skills. With constant supervision and support from group and center members she took her first loan of $40 in 2006. From previous investments she succeeded in providing lunch to workers at construction and other job-sites.

With a loan of $200, she plans to increase her stock by buying beans, drum of oil and pig feed. She will continue to provide lunch to laborers at job-sites and families that are busy to cook for themselves or for ceremonies. She plans to pay her loan in 15 months. First loan repayment installment shall be made on the first month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Mobile Koki restaurant

loans.name: Sadiah

texts.en: S. is 55 years old. She sells rice cooked in coconut milked and crackers. She lives by herself as all her children are married and live separately. Sometimes she sells fish. She wants to have a bigger loan to fund her business of selling fish.

loans.use: Buy fish to sell

loans.name: Wartisem

texts.en: W. is a 45 year-old mother with one child, aged 20. She has been managing her business by selling cooked foods in a small restaurant for 20 years. She usually earns $10 per day. She opens the small restaurant from 5 pm – 2 am everyday. Her husband, Dakir, is a fisherman and sells fish in the fish market, earning $2. She needs a bigger loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Small restaurant

loans.name: Nengsih

texts.en: N. is 36 years old and is married with four children, aged 19, 16, 8 and 1. The first three are girls and the last one is a boy. She sells kerosene, some snacks, and other household goods in a small booth. Her husband, Nali, is a fisherman with unfixed income. She can earns $6 per day and will need a larger loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Jenab

texts.en: J. is 36 years old and is married with three children, aged 17, 13 and 8. She sells household goods whereas her husband does not have fixed income. She could earn $15/day with a profit of $2-$5/day. She very much needs bigger loan to make her shop complete and sustained.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Toyibah

texts.en: T. is 24 years old and is married with one child, aged 3. She sells ice blended in front of her house. She usually earns a profit of $1.5 per day whereas her husband, Sukron, is a fisherman whose  income is unfixed, earning only $2 - $3 per day.  She very much needs to have loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Munaya

texts.en: M. is 33 years old and is married with three children, aged 14, 6 and 3. She sells fish crackers and chips whereas her husband, Ma’ruf, sells waste and scrap materials. She was very glad to hear about MBK and decided to become a member. She sells the crackers and chips by consigning them at the small shop in her village. She could earn $5 - $10/day. Now she can live better than before, she can save some money and send her children to school. She is expecting the bigger loan to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Edita

texts.en:
Edita is the owner of a convenience store. She began by selling candies from her home. Edita’s siblings helped her open her store when she separated from her husband. Edita will use the loan to invest in purchasing school supplies and convenience items so that she can expand her business to include school and office supplies, as she has noted that these products are not offered in her area. She believes that with this investment, her sales will increase. This will allow her to continue helping her daughter with her university studies. Edita is 50 years old. She has an 18 year old daughter and is separated from her husband. She is totally dependant on her business for the support of her family. She is concerned about her daughter’s education, and she would like to see her become a professional. She is an enterprising woman and she knows that her business will grow, giving her the financial security that she needs.

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer.

Edita tiene una Tienda donde vende viveres de primera necesidad. Ella comenzo vendiendo confiteria en su casa .Edita empezo su negocio con la ayuda de sus hermanos al separarse de su esposo. Edita usara el prestamo para invertir en comprar en útiles escolares y viveres para asi poder ampliar su negocio con productos escolares y de oficina porque se ha dado cuenta que por sus sector no hay este negocio. Ella esta convencida que con esta inversión sus ventas creceran. Esto le permitirá seguir ayudando a su hija con los estudios universitarios. Edita tiene 50 años, es separada y tiene 1 hija de 18 años. Ella depende totalmente de su negocio para ayudar a su familia. Ella se preocupa por la educacion de sus hija quiere verla una profesional. Es una mujer emprendedora y sabe que su negocio crecera y le dara la seguridad financiera que necesita.

loans.use: Investment in school supplies

loans.name: Maritza

texts.en:
Martiza owns a store and bazaar. She sells groceries and school supplies. Her husband, who had worked at a market, helped her start the business. They began with $300 in capital, which they invested in adapting her house for the business and purchasing some stock. Maritza will use the loan to buy groceries and school supplies at wholesale prices. Her business is located close to her district’s schools, which makes for good daily sales. Maritza is 25 years old, married, and has two children. Her husband is her right hand in the business and is in charge of making purchases in the market. She is confident that her sales will increase and will improve her family’s quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Susanna Heinz, Kiva Volunteer.

Maritza tiene una tienda y bazar. Se dedica a la venta de viveres y utiles escolares. Ella empezo su negocio con la ayuda de su esposo quien anteriormente habia trabajado en un mercado. Comenzaron con un capital de $300 dolares que invirtieron en la adecuacion de su hogar y un poco de mercaderia. Maritza usara el prestamo para comprar viveres a precio de mayorista y papeleria. Su negocio esta muy bien ubicado cerca de escuelas del sector ayudando esto para que sus ventas diarias sean buenas. Maritza tiene 25 años esta unida tiene 2 hijos su esposo es su mano derecha en el negocio el se encarga de las compras en el mercado. Ella esta segura que sus ventas se incrementaran y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: Purchasing her products at wholesale prices

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.en:
Tomasa sells imitation jewelry and cosmetics in her neighborhood and in rural villages. She got into the business by helping a friend with her sales. At first she only sold jewelry like rings, chains, and bracelets, but now she sells these products as well as cosmetics and purses.

Tomasa hopes to sell electric appliances such as rice cookers, irons, and mixers since her customers are asking for these products.

Tomasa is 37 years old, has 3 children and is separated. It has been hard for her to get ahead in life because she can only depend on her business to support her family. She hopes that this loan will stabilize her business and give her more security in life.

Tomasa se dedica a la venta de bisuteria y cosmeticos en su sector y en pueblos rurales. Ella empezo el negocio ayudando en las ventas de Bisuteria a una amiga. Al principio solo vendia Bisuteria como anillos, cadenas y pulseras, pero ahora continua vendiendo estos productos junto con cosmeticos y carteras. Tomasa aspira vender productos eléctricos como ollas arroceras, planchas y batidoras ya que sus clientes le estan demandando estos productos. Tomasa tien 37 años, es separada y tiene 3 hijos. Le ha sido muy duro salir adelante con su familia porque ella depende totalmente de su negocio para mentener a sus hijos. Ella tiene la esperanza que con este prestamo podra establecerse su negocio y tener un poco mas de estabilidad y seguridad en su vida.

loans.use: Purchase home electric appliances

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys sells chickens and eggs to nearby stores and to her neighbors. She started her business with the help of her mother who gave her $200 with which to start the business. Initially she only sold to her family members and friends but she gradually expanded her business in order to sell to stores and markets. She aspires to sell dairy products like cheese, milk and yogurt. She will use the loan to invest in these products and in chickens. She believes that the business will grow and her profits will increase with the introduction of these new products. She is sure that this increase in sales will allow her to better educate her four children, all of whom are in school.

Translated from Spanish by Susanna Heinz, Kiva Volunteer.

Gladys se dedica a la venta de pollos y huevos a tiendas y vecinos del sector. Ella empezo su negocio con la ayuda de su madre quien le facilito $ 200 dolares para que emprendiera el negocio. Al principio solo vendia para sus familiares y amigos y poco fue creciendo para poder vender a tiendas y mercados. Ella aspira vender productos lacteos como queso, leche y yogurt .Gladys usara el prestamo para invertir en productos lacteos y pollos .Ella tiene Fe que que con la introduccion de estos nuevos productos sus ganacias se incrementaran y su negocio crecera. Ella esta segura que sus ventas crecera y le podra dar una mejor educacion a sus hijos. Gladys tiene 4 hijos y todos estudian. Ella ayuda en el hogar con las ganancias de su negocio. Junto con el sueldo que gana su esposo, ellos pueden proveer a sus hijos con comida y educación. Tiene la seguridad que con la inversion que hara le permitira tener mejores ganancias y poder ayudar con una mejor educacion para sus hijos.

loans.use: Investment in dairy products like cheese and yogurt

loans.name: Rosalba

texts.en:
Rosalba is a single mother of two children. She lives with her mother and father on their lands, after being left by her husband just a year ago. Despite the difficult situation, Rosalba wants to get ahead by investing this loan on her parents land. Since she was young she has been living off of the rice production from the farm, and she is now looking to make investments that will help her family keep more profits. She hopes that with the loan she will one day have a home of her own for her and her children, ages 5 and 1.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Rosalba is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Invest in Rice Production

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Xuan

texts.en:
Mrs Xuan’s husband left her for another woman. She is supporting a child by herself. The child is 16 years old and in grade 8. Mrs Xuan has a small hut with wooden walls and a clay floor. She has a small rice field of about 280 m2. She also buys waste daily for recycling and then sells it to a a small business in the commune. Additionally, she raises pigs at her house.

Mrs Xuan borrowed an interest-free loan of $100 and has already repaid the loan. Her income increased $2.50 per person per month. Now the average income is $10 per person per month. Mrs Xuan wants another loan of $100 for expanding her business.

loans.use: Selling recycled waste and raising pigs.

loans.name: Santos

texts.en:
Despite Santos' 66 years of age, he is still a hard-working farmer. He has had three kids, who are all independent now. He works his lands in order to support him and his wife. He has been living on this land for over 40 years. He is proud of his farm because it has allowed him to feed and educate his children. Santos only has a limited education, but through hard work and reliance on his experience, he ensures the investment in rice will be successful.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Santos is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Invest in Rice production

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes has been living her farm for about 20 years. The plot of land she owns was given to her by her parents, whom she still works closely with. On her farm she primarily grows rice, but she also raises cattle and chickens. Whenever she can, she ventures into the larger markets of the city to sell the animals or the rice from her farm. She is optimistic about having a source of investment capital for her production because she will be able to afford seeds and fertilizer that will increase her productivity.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Mercedes is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is a rice farmer in the rural sector of Ecuador. He has lived in Santa Lucia his entire life. Although he is now separated from his wife, he still maintains close contact with his kids, only one of which is still in school. He hopes that he can invest the money from the loan in increasing his production. Thanks to the help of his farm association he feels that he can commercialize his product well if he has enough to sell.

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio has lived on his lands for about 40 years. He has 6 children, all of whom are grown. Some of his sons still work with him on the farm during the heavy cycles of rice production. He has depended on his lands for his entire life. He also has some cattle that he raises and uses for milk production. Julio will invest the loan mainly in pesticides and the rental of machinery to pick the rice he has already planted. The loan will help increase his profits as he will not lose as much production as before and it will be easier to collect his product.

Hector O. has been living on his farm for about 20 years. He has been a rice farmer since he was young. He completely relies on the production from his lands to maintain himself and his family. He still lives on the lands with his parents, who work with him on the farm. loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario has over 30 years of experience farming rice. Because his parents did not send him to school beyond 5th grade, he must rely on his rice farming knowledge to feed his family. He has two kids, aged 10 and 16. He hopes that he can provide them with better a better future than his by giving them an education. With the loan he will invest in machinery for collecting the raise after it has grown. With the profits he hopes to make improvements to his home.

He travels to local markets to sell the livestock when ever he is in need of extra money.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel is a farmer in the Santa Lucia County, where he has lived for twenty years. He is 63 years old, but he still has the will to work and provide for his family. He has a 14 year-old that he wants to make sure finishes school. Manuel is hoping to receive the loan in order to improve the production of his lands. He will primarily buy fertilizer and fumigation equipment. He and his wife Benita hope to save for the future of their son.

There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice Farming

loans.name: Jorge

texts.en:
Jorge has a farm in Santa Lucia, Ecuador. He plants rice and also raises pigs. He has been living on the lands for about 30 years. He primarily relies on rice to feed his wife and two kids, aged 15 and 9. Whenever he is in need of extra capital he goes and sells some pigs in the local market. This has been a great fallback for him and his family. He plans to use most of the money from the loan in rice production. He will purchase pesticides and invest in machinery to help in the collection process.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Jorge is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. loans.name: William

texts.en:
William M. has a small piece of land in rural Ecuador that he uses in order to cultivate rice. Although his farm is small, it has been providing for him and his family for over 30 years. He is now seeking to make an investment in order to reap more benefits from the land. He wants to invest in fertilizers and pesticides in order to better care for his main crop, rice. William and his family also raise pigs and chicken on their farm, only selling them when they are in need of money. William has his rice processed and commercialized at his associations facilities, where he also works part time.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

William is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.en:
Victor Manuel has a farm where he has raised all nine of his children over the last 40 years. He is a very hard worker as he had to rely on his lands in order to feed his family. He has made efforts to educate some of his kids, but just as his parents could not afford to send him to school past the elementary level, there were times when he could not afford to educate all nine children. He still lives with some of his sons who help him on the farm. They all work the fields together in order to cultivate rice and sell it in the city. He hopes the loan will help him be more productive.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan has lived off of rice farming almost his life. He is 70 years old and still has the energy to oversee his lands. With the help of his son, who still lives and works the fields with him, his rice farming is still productive. He and his wife Damiana are very happy to receive the loan, especially at their age which makes it particularly difficult to borrow even from informal lenders and loan sharks. He hopes he can invest in his land so they will continue to be productive for the next generation of his family.

Juan is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. loans.name: Fermin

texts.en:
Fermin is a very hard-working rice farmer from Santa Lucia. Despite his elementary education and old age, Fermin has been able to and continues to run his farm very effectively. It has always provided for him and his 5 children. Although they are all grown up now, his kids still help in the farm and some even still live at home. To them, the "hacienda" is more than a home, as it has been in the family for over 40 years and it also puts food on the table. He hopes he can invest in seeds and fertilizer for the next planting season.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Fermin is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. loans.name: Aurelio

texts.en:
Aurelio has 20 years of experience farming rice. He was born and raised in Santa Lucia and helped his father farm when he was young. His three kids have also followed the family trade and help him on his farm. He and his wife Nancy are optimistic about receiving the loan because it will allow them to invest in their lands. They want to maximize their productivity by purchasing fertilizer and pesticides that will help nurture the crop. They will also use the loan to rent machinery that will make the picking process much easier.

loans.name: Dionicio

texts.en:
Dionicio has lived in Santa Lucia for about 50 years. As most of the other people in the sector, he has gone through life thanks to the fertile lands that produce rice. He has raised 5 children thanks to the help of his rice farming. He is now hoping that he can receive a loan in order to improve his farm and leave his children with more productive lands. He has had 5 children in total and he is happy that they have grown up but still help him on the family's farm.

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Jesus has been living in Santa Lucia for about 25 years. He has been farming rice since he was a young man since he did not finish school and only had the skills passed down by his father to rely on. With his work he has provided for five children, three of which are still in school (ages 7, 10 and 15). With the loan he hopes to make an investment in seeds and fertilizer to reap more from his lands. Jesus hopes to make some improvements in his home with the extra profits, as well as secure the education for his children.

This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Tabriz

texts.en: Tabriz was born in 1981 in the Salyan region, Yenikand village. He is single. He is a very responsible man. His first loan of $400 dollars was used to buy foodstuffs to stock his grocery store. Now he requests an $800 loan to buy a refrigerator, which will enable him to stock and sell foodstuffs which are in demand, but require refrigeration.

loans.use: To buy refrigerator

loans.name: Ngon

texts.en: Ngon N. and her husband live in Phnom Penh, Cambodia and are the parents of nine children.  N. grows rice in the rainy season, while her husband works as a musician and can earn up to $500 per year.  Five of their children help them to grow crops, while the others are construction workers and factory workers.  N. and her husband hope to use part of this loan to buy a motorcycle taxi that their son can drive to help supplement the family's income.  They hope to use the rest of the loan to buy a machine so that they can increase their annual rice production.

loans.use: To buy a machine to help harvest crops and to buy a motorcycle to use as taxi

loans.name: Yadiyar

texts.en:
24-year-old Yadiyar is a mother of 2 children. She  lives in Salyan region Yenikand village. She has 3 years experience in this business. She works very hard for the success of her children. With this business she meets the demands of her family.
Now Yadiyar needs a loan of $500 to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Nay

texts.en: Nay Y. is 54 years old and the mother of four children.  In the past two years, the family has created several sources of income.  Y. plants corn and raises the family's five cows, which they plan to sell soon to a local butcher.  Her husband runs a fishery and can make up to five dollars per day in the high season.  Y.'s two sons are construction workers and make about four dollars per day.  Meanwhile, her two daughters each make $70 per month while working in a garment factory.  Y. plans to use this loan to buy a machine to help harvest crops.  Additionally, the family will buy one more cow to raise.

loans.use: To increase corn production and to buy a cow

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Nay Yoeung and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Shahbaz

texts.en: Shahbaz is 57-years old, married, has 5 children. He lives in Salyan region, Khaladj village. He breeds lambs and cattle, a business he has worked in for 20 years. With his first loan of $400, he bought five lambs and a calf. He is now requesting a loan of $900 to purchase a milk cow.

loans.use: To buy a milch cow

loans.name: Ngorn

texts.en: Ngorn P. is 47 years old and the mother of four children.  She plants crops for her family and also for others.  This business activity generates about $2.50 per day.  P.'s husband is a construction worker and typically makes between $4.00 and $6.00 per day.  One of her sons helps her grow the crops and two of them work construction with their father.  P.'s daughter works at a garment factory and can make up to $100 a month.  The family plans to use this loan to buy more corn seeds and also to buy a cow to raise.

loans.use: To buy seeds to plant corn and to buy a cow

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mahabbat

texts.en: Mahabbat is 37-years old, married and has two children. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region, Kilsali village, settled in Khirdalan settlement. Mahabbat has rented this paper-mill for 12 years. She buys paper-manufactured products as raw materials, cuts the paper with benches and prepares new papers in different formats for selling. Mahabbat began her business with a loan of $500 to buy paint and paper. Now she requests a loan of $1200 to buy more paint and paper which will allow her to expand production and offer employment to others in her region. She loves her work and is excited to be engaged in this business.

loans.use: To buy paint and paper

loans.name: Nol

texts.en: Nol S. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and eight children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  She works planting corn and gathering fish in the rainy season.  Her husband, meanwhile, is a construction worker and makes about $2.50 per day.  Three of her sons work construction with their father, one of her daughters works in a garment factory, and the other four children help to grow crops.  The family plans to use this loan to buy more corn seeds and also to buy a machine to help harvest their crops.  Additionally, they hope to buy a boat to help them gather fish during the rainy season.

loans.use: To buy a machine to help harvest crops and to buy a boat to gather fish

Four years ago he decided to start his own business. 
For his first loan, he borrowed $400 to buy a pregnant cow. The second time he borrowed a loan of $700 and bought a pregnant cow and a pregnant sheep.
Now he requests a loan of $1200 to buy ten pregnant sheep.

loans.use: to buy ten pregnant sheep

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Gina is 32 years old and a mother of 2 children. She had no education at all. She therefore supports her husband in catering for the family needs with her "kenkey" business. She has been in the business for the past 3 years and has a fairly good client base.

Her major issue is the sourcing of maize which is the major component of her "kenkey" operations. Having gone through the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION, she wants to access the KIVA loan to buy the maize up-front and do away with the credit regime she operates with now.

loans.use: Workig Capital

loans.name: Eldaniz

texts.en:
This young man is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region.  He settled in the Khirdalan settlement and is now married.

Eldaniz is a 28-year-old man who started his business 5 years ago.
Now he needs a loan of $700 to buy womens scarves and children's blouses. 
He plans to expand his business and increase the number of clients he has.

loans.use: to buy womens scarves for and childrens blouses

loans.name: Pauline Zi

texts.en:
Pauline is a mother of seven children. The mysterious death of her daughter and sister coupled with the fact that her husband lost his job at an early age and she has had to struggle alone to educate their children and to pay for medication has been strength and source of motivation. She is a seven-time borrower. With her six previous loans she succeeded in provided her community with firewood, pork, manure and fresh raw food stuff. Her good business gained her the name “Mami Firewood” in her community.

Given a loan of $1200, she plans to buy table birds to rear and sell at Christmas, fortify her existing pig-fence, give her son small capital and buy seeds for cultivation. She is optimistic and plans to pay her loan with income from sales of firewood, manure and vegetables.

She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling firewood and sundries

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 34 years old and married with 2 children. She resides with the family in a community where majority of the residents are in the upper-middle income bracket. She therefore runs a general provisions store to meet the needs of the inhabitants.

Her desire is to expand the stock of the store. She benefited from the 'TEACH' learning sessions facilitated by KRABAN in October last year. She therefore looks forward in putting the KIVA loan to maximum use for an improvement in her family's life.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Nadjafgulu

texts.en:
Nadjafgulu has been in the business of cattle breeding for 14 years. He breeds calves. 
He was born in 1950 in the Salyan region.  He is married and has 3 children.
With this business, he is able to meet the financial demands of his family.
He requests a loan of $500 to buy fodder for his calves.

loans.use: to buy fodder

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Connie is 56 and married with 6 childern who attend school. Her husband is no longer earning any income, thus placing a greater burden on Connie.

It was during the KRABAN 'TEACH' learning facilitation that she decided to take advantage of the KIVA facility to change her fortune. All along she been faced with high credit payments to her supplier. She hopes to buy the maize with cash in her "kenkey" business and thus increase her profit margin substantially.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Yashar

He has a plot of land on which he grows vines and strawberries. 
He needs a loan of $500 to buy fertilizer and expand his plot of land.
He has 3 years of experience in this business.

loans.name: Zamig

texts.en:
Zamig is 27 years old and lives in Yenihand village in the  Salyan region.  He is single. Zamig has 2 years of experience in this business. He provides for his family by selling milk. He wishes to increase his income by buying a milch cow.
He needs a loan of $500 to buy a milch cow.
This business is his only source of income.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:

Since the constant trekking is having an effect on her health, she wants to use the KIVA loan to acquire a small stall where she can sit and display her goods.

With a loan of $500 she bought a printing machine. Hagigat also rented a paper mill.  She requests a loan of $1000 to repair the paper mill.

Having taken part in the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN, she hopes to utilise the KIVA loan to add other products frequently asked for by her clients.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Khalig

Now he requests a loan of $1000 to buy five pregnant sheep and two calves.

She took part in the 'TEACH' learning sessions organised by KRABAN last year. As a hairdresser, her objective in joining the program is to seek assistance to acquire some working tools like dryers, both standing and hand ones. This would help to reduce the turn-around time for her clients and increase sales.

loans.use: Working Capital

She requests a loan of $500 to buy fertilizer.
She has 15 years of experience in this business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Lizzy is a mother of 4 children and is 43 years old. She had education up to the secondary level and operates a general store in her community. She has run this over the past 5 years and has been able to acquire a metal container shop from her own resources. This has reduced her capital.

As a graduate of the KRABAN 'TEACH' learning sessions, she intends to utilise the KIVA loan to support her capital base and expand the product range.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Namik

texts.en:
Namik is 28 years old and is single.  He lives in Khaladj village in the Salyan region.

Four years ago, Namik decided to start his own business. Having borrowed $600, he bought three calves. Now he requests a loan of $1200 to buy an additional five meaty calves.

loans.use: to buy five meaty calves

loans.name: Lem Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca is married wit four children. She likes business but has limited capital. She applied for her first loan in 2003. She invested in pig farming. With training on business management and profit from the business, there was need for another loan to expand and also do trading (buyam-sellam). She lost all her animals but never got discouraged. She is applying for her third loan.

With this $800 she is determined to revised her business and add more articles because of demand from the community. She plans to buy in bulk dry fish, "egusi", crayfish, and beans to retail and supply to other people to sell. Also she will buy 2 piglets. With the profit from this business she is determined to buy farming land for herself.

loans.use: Buy food for distribution; piglets

loans.name: Numfor Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a single mother of three. She attended medical school and also training on pig farming. There is high demand for her services from her neighbors who cannot pay for public consultation fees. In addition, most of her neighbors collect the droppings of the pigs for manure on their farms. This increases food yields there and reduces hunger and malnutrition.

However she was prevented from operating a big medicine store because of finances. With loans from GHAPE, she opened a small store and bought piglets. Profit from the business helped her to fit doors and widows in her building. With high demand from the community, there is need for expansion.

Given $500, she is prepared to expand this business and buy more medicine together with four piglets and eight bags of feed. This will enable her to earn more profit to educate her children.

loans.use: Pharmacy and pig farming

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 39 years old and married with 4 children. She completed basic education and did a catering course at the vocational level. With this background, she began a fast-food joint some 7 years ago. This has grown steadily and she has added a general store also.

The KRABAN 'TEACH' learning sessions further increased the desire to improve customer satisfaction. She has therefore decided to use the KIVA assistance to improve the environment in which she operates in order to give value to her teeming clients.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Benjamin Paa Kow

texts.en:
Ben is 38 years old and married with 1 child. He was educated up to G.C.E. Advanced level. From his own meagre resources, he was able to establish an auto parts shop which he still operates. Items on sale include bolts and nuts, refurbished radiators and other assorted used car parts.

He has benefited from KRABAN'S 'TEACH' learning sessions. He wants to use the KIVA loan to stock up other items like used rims, tyres and lubricants for sale.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Cristian Alejandro

texts.en:
Cristian is 22 years old, he is married and has a little son one year old. He got started selling shoes because the salary he was earning was very low and insufficient to support his family. After the birth of his son, the family's expenses increased and he convinced his wife that together they should sell shoes, offering their customers a payment plan. Cristian is an enterprising man and very hardworking, he wants to give the best to his family and now he wants to see his business grow.

At present, Cristian needs a loan for the amount of $200.00, which he will use toward the purchase of merchandise, in order to offer better variety to his customers and to be able to obtain greater income to provide the necessities for his family. Cristian needs your collaboration. With your help he can do great things. Please decide to support him.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Flor Idalia

texts.en:
Flor is originally from the town of Monclova in the state of Coahuila, she is married and has two small children. Three years ago, when her husband found himself unemployed and it was very hard for him to find work, the family went through a very difficult economic situation. In order to support her family, Flor started selling cosmetics and ceramic figurines, and in that way she was able to provide food to her family during that crisis. Today, her husband works in a fruit store, but Flor continues with her business because it has gone very well and her customers have increased. She hopes her business will get bigger so she can help her family and contribute to the education of her children.

Presently Flor needs a loan in the amount of $175.00 which she will use toward the purchase of merchandise to meet the demands of her customers and to grow her business. Today is the day to help someone who really needs it. Flor and her family thank you sincerely.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Julio César

texts.en:
Julio César is married and has four children, 13, 9, and 4 years and the youngest just 9 months old. Two years ago, he fount himself without work, and because he had little academic education it was difficult to find any. The debts of the household and the children's school kept accumulating. In order to cover them, he started selling cosmetics to his relatives and neighbors, and today his customers have multiplied.

Julio has worked hard so that his children can continue with their studies, because he thinks it is very important for their future. At the moment, he needs a loan of $250.00, which he will use to buy merchandise. He hopes with the greater investment, he will be able to obtain greater income to buy the necessities for his family. There is no doubt that you can help this family. Please decide to support them.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Maria Luisa Guadalup

texts.en:
Maria Luisa is married, she has one son 9 years old and two daugters aged 4 years and 3 months. Her son became ill one year ago, and the injections that he needed were very costly. Her husband works as a driver and his income did not cover all the necessities for the family, much less the medication her son needed. That's when Maria Luisa started working. She started out selling shoes and silver jewelry in order to pay for her son's injections.

Now Maria Luisa needs a loan in the amount of $200.00, which she plans to repay in a term of 4 to 8 months. She will use it to buy merchandise to help her business grow. Maria Luisa is a very hardworking woman who wants a better quality of life for her family. Now she needs your help. You can help this family, don't doubt it.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
Ms. Nieves has worked for 10 years running a hotel. She is an enterprising woman and very hardworking. She is married and has one daughter, and started this business to be able to provide the necessities for her family. There were some financial problems with her business some time ago, but with the support of her family and friends she was able to overcome them. Now she wants her hotel, located in downtown Monclova, Coahuila (her home town), to grow and be a successful business.

At present, Nieves needs a loan of just $475.00, which she will use to remodel her hotel, in order to keep it the way her customers like it and to offer better service. She knows that she can repay the loan within the term of 4 to 8 months, because she is confident that with these modifications her hotel will produce better profits. You can be a part of this growth, don't doubt it. Please decicde to support Nieves and her family. They thank you sincerely.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: Remodeling

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Ms. Silvia is a very active woman, responsible and hardworking. She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a farmer, and given the conditions of his work, his income is seasonal and they have lacked many of the necessities. For this reason, twenty years ago Silvia started selling shoes. She started out selling to neighbors and relatives, but today she has many customers and the orders for her products have increased.

Silvia wants to offer her children a better life, and the wants them to finish their studies. She needs a loan in the amount of $250.00, which she will use to buy merchandise to meet the demands of her customers and to obtain greater income. Your support will be very helpful to this family, without a doubt. Today is the day to help. Silvia and her family thank you sincerely.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Clara Lorenza

texts.en:
For the past 12 years, Clara Lorenza has worked selling fruit and vegetables in the market at Mérida, in the state of Yucatán, in southern Mexico. Since she acquired the location, she has dedicated herself completely to this business. She has one son age 17, and she wants him to finish his studies. Clara has worked very hard, and her strength and dedication have permitted her to stay in business for so long. Today, she has obtained a larger location, and she needs to stock more fruits and vegetables to fill it. For that reason she needs a loan of $550.00.

You can be a part of the growth of this business. Clara promises to pay back the loan in 4 to 8 months. The power to help this family is in your hands, without a doubt. Please decide to support them. Clara needs your collaboration and she thanks you for your support and caring.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Laura Patricia

texts.en:
Laura Patricia is a single mother with one son, age 14, and one daughter, age 12. She started her butcher shop 15 years ago, investing all her savings into it, and little by little her business gained more clients and grew. 'Paty' works arduously at her butcher shop, which is located in Progreso, in the state of Yucatán, in order to provide the necessities for her children, so that they will have the chance to study and create a better quality of life.

At present the whole family works together in the butcher shop. The number of customers has grown, and for that reason Paty needs a loan in the amount of $750.00, which she will use to buy meat and vegetables to vary her stock and offer greater variety and better service to her customers. You can be an important part of the growth of this business. Your assistance will be a great help to this family.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Vic is a mother of 6 children and is 45 years old. She had basic level of education. With the help of her husband she set up a shop that deals in the sale of used drums (jerricans). These have various uses in our country. They include water storage, alcohol processing and preservation. The market for drums is increasing every day since water is becoming a scarce commodity in our part of the world. She would therefore want to access the KIVA loan to increase her stock to expand her share of the market.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Jane is a young woman of 28 with no children. She had her education to junior school level. She went into baking some 4 years ago using a brick oven that is fired with wood.

Having taken part in the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION, she decided to access the KIVA loan. Her objective is to acquire a gas oven to reduce the workload on her and also the cost of producing a loaf of bread. This she firmly believes would result in an increase in her income.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 47 years old and married with 4 children. She had education up to the basic level. Together with her husband, she operates a motor/bicycle shop which displays a wide range of imported spare parts. Even though automobiles are available, a lot of people use this means of transport as well. Thus market for spares is very encouraging.

She would therefore like to access the KIVA loan to expand the range of spares available to her clients.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kwabena

texts.en:
Kwabena is 37 years old and a father of 3 children who are in school. He had education up to the basic level. Some 7 years ago, he branched out into the sale of VCD/DVD compact discs and currently is one of the major distributors in the city. He also benefited from the KRABAN 'TEACH' learning sessions in October last year.

He has plans to expand the volumes of discs but is largely restricted by the size of his shop. He thus intends to utilise the KIVA loan to acquire a secured shed to strengthen his operations.

loans.use: Shed Acquisition

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Lizzy is 44 years old and a mother of 3 children. Her education ended at the basic level. She is textile dealer in the Central Business District of the city, where her shop is located. She has been in the trade for over 10 years and has a lot of experience in the business.

She wants to access the KIVA loan to reduce her level of dependence on creditors to fund the business. This would also result in a proportionate increase in her profit margins.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Baaba  Dacosta

texts.en:
Baaba is 36 years old, married with 4 children and an expectant mother as well. She runs a pub that dispenses local and foreign gin in her community. Coupled with good music, she has a responsive market. Baaba had secretarial training which she is properly harnessing to serve her clients and is actually yielding positive results.

She intends to use the KIVA loan to improve the environment in order to give real value to her customers.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 34 years old and a mother of 4 children. She had education up to the basic level.S he followed up with a vocation in dressmaking and came out as a qualified seamstress 3 years later. She currently runs her own shop in her community and plans to engage apprentices who want to train as well. She therefore wants the KIVA loan to purchase 4 additional sewing machines so as to be able to get contracts from schools and organisations.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Seth

texts.en:
Seth is 45 years old and a father. He had only a basic education. He runs a general store in the Central Business District of the city. He deals in items like automatic rice cookers, deep freezers and other electrical appliances.

Having benefited from the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN, Seth anticipates turning round his business with the KIVA loan and increasing the size of his market substantially.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Nguon

texts.en:
Nguon N. is 32 years old and a mother of 2. She lives in Phnom Penh City with her husband, two children, her brother, and her sister. She makes her living buying vegetables in bulk at the local market, and reselling them to restaurants for a small markup. She can make between $1.25 and $5.00 per day in her business. Her brother and sister also work, and supplement her income in return for living in Mrs. N.'s home.

In the future, Nguon N. dreams of building a new house. Also, she would like to change her job to selling clothes in the market where the profits are larger than what she receives now.

loans.use: Extend her vegetable selling business

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem C. is 24 years old and the mother of 3. She lives in Phnom Penh City, and she and her husband run a small game stand by the riverside. She sells balloons, small toys, and offers prizes for people that play her games. Together, she and her husband can make $10 per day in their business. She also is raising 3 cows for future income.

In the future, she hopes to continue growing her business and extending it to more locations.

loans.use: Buy more games for small carnival on the riverside.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Bun Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Bun Thoeun is 37 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She is a tailor and makes about $2.50 per day. Her husband, moreover, works as an employee at the Post of Telecommunication and makes about $80 per month. 
With this kind of loan, she intends to use it for repairing her house and extending her tailoring business. Furthermore, she hopes to buy more sewing machines and other equipments to facilitate her business.

loans.use: To repair house and extend tailoring business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Asai wants to buy six steers to be grazed for at least six months and then be sold one by one

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Grace wants to increase the supply of building blocks by hiring at least three more lorries

loans.use: Kukuya would like to buy 6 steer to restock her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
