En días ordinarios (es decir no feriados o Domingos) realiza la venta ambulante por la ciudad, este trabajo lo realiza en compañía de su esposo e hijos , es decir que es el núcleo familiar el que colabora para que este negocio siga adelante ya que es su único medio de ingresos. La fidelidad con la Institución y el antecedente histórico de cumplimiento le permite acceder a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: José Andrés

texts.en:
Ten years ago, José Andrés was unemployed and started a snack shop and later added video games to his business. He has six kids, and currently is separated from his wife. He cares for his youngest daughter, 18, and his little granddaughter. José's business has been growing little by little, and thanks to the good service he offers he has been able to keep happy customers for some time.

Currently, José needs a $325 loan to use on maintenance for the video games and to purchase supplies for his snack shop so he can offer a wider variety of products. He wants to proviD. a better quality of life to his daughter and granddaughter and wants to see his business continue to grow. You can help both causes.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Hace 10 años, José Andrés se quedó desempleado e inició con la venta D. snack y después incorporó el servicio D. maquinitas D. videojuegos. Él tiene seis hijos, actualmente vive separado D. su esposa y tiene a su cargo a su hija menor D. 18 años D. edad y D. su pequeña nieta. El negocio D. Don José ha ido creciendo poco a poco, y gracias al buen servicio que ofrece ha podido permanecer en el gusto D. sus clientes por tanto tiempo.

Ahora, José necesita D. un préstamo por la cantidad D. $ 325 dólares que utilizará en el mantenimiento D. los videojuegos y para la compra D. mercancías para su snack con una mayor variedad D. productos. Él quiere ofrecerles una mejor calidad D. vida a su hija y a su nieta, y quiere ver crecer su negocio, tú puedes ayudar a esta familia, apóyalos.

loans.use: Buy supplies for snack shop and maintenance for video games.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Lizzy is 35 years old and married, with 4 children. She had a basic education but very determined to succeed. She operates a pub that dispenses both alcoholic and non alcoholic beverages. They include some of the popular brands in the country. After participating in the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN, she is poised to take advantage of a KIVA loan to improve her business and better her lot and that of the family.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucía is married and has two kids, ages 6 and 2. Five years ago, shortly after the birth of her first son, family expenses increased and her husband's salary could not cover them all. So Lucía, who didn't want to neglect her baby, began selling beauty products via catalogue to her neighbors and relatives. It went well for her, since she's a good saleswoman and offered comfortable payment plans. After a little while, she decided to buy clothes with the money she had saved, and began selling that as well. Since that time, she has dedicated herself to the sale of beauty products and clothing.

Lucía currently wishes to increase her sales, which is why she's asking for a loan of $1,200. She will repay it within two to four months, since she plans on investing this money and moving her products quickly. From her experience, she has learned the good seasons to sell her product and how to regain her investment. Lucía awaits your help to allow her business to continue to grow and help her confront the building family expenses as her children get older.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Lucía esta casada y tiene dos hijos, uno de 6 años de edad y el otro de 2 años; hace cinco años atrás luego del nacimiento de su primer hijo, los gastos familiares se incrementaron y con el sueldo de su esposo no era suficiente para cubrir estos gastos, por lo que Lucía para no descuidar a su hijo que era un bebe, empezó ofreciendo productos de belleza por catalogo a sus familiares y vecinos y le fue muy bien, ya que ella también es buena vendedora y los planes de pago eran cómodos para sus clientes, así con el paso del tiempo y con un pequeño capital que logró ahorrar decidió comprar ropa para venderla también y desde entonces se dedica a la venta de ropa y de artículos de belleza.

Lucía actualmente desea incrementar su negocio por lo que requiere de un préstamo por US $ 1,200 los cuales ofrece pagar en un período de 2 a 4 meses, ya que piensa invertir este dinero y darle una rotación bastante rápida a sus productos, por que ella sabe de las temporadas buenas y de cómo recuperar su inversión lo cual lo ha aprendido con la experiencia. Lucía espera su ayuda para continuar creciendo y así poder enfrentar los gastos que se incrementan a medida que sus hijos van creciendo.

loans.use: Buy beauty products and clothing.

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.en: My name is Alejandrina, and I sell clothing for men, women and children ages 3 and up. This business has helped me cover my family’s expenses and pay for my children’s education. Mother’s Day is coming up, and I need to stock my inventory with new merchandise to be able to offer my clients a larger variety of clothing and good prices.

loans.use: Purchase of button-down shirts, skirts, sweaters, pants, etc.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia is 26 years old and a mother of 3 children. She completed basic education decided thereafter to trade. She currently prepares a local food made with maize. Fried, it is a staple for the majority of the inhabitants in the community.She intends to use a KIVA loan to procure her maize supplies directly from the market and eliminate the high price demanded by her creditors.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Alixis Esplenda

texts.en: I sell quality second-hand clothing, and I use my earnings to support my children. I have been doing this job for two years since I have been unable to find steady work and need to help my family. Selling used clothing is a good business since not everyone is economically able to pay for new clothes in stores.

loans.use: Purchase of quality second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Berkie is 50 years old and a mother of 7 children. She has a basic education. Her trade is the processing of oil palm fruits and kernels for sale. She supplies the finished product to specific customers who use them in the manufacture of local soap. She intends to use a KIVA loan to purchase more kernels since the rains would begin in this part of the country.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.en: I work selling homemade meals since I have two school-age children. Thus, I need the help of new funds to stock my inventory and improve sales.

loans.use: Purchase of tortillas, frijoles, bananas, eggs, cheese, meat, etc.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 34 years old and married with 3 children. She was educated to a basic level. She deals in the sale of used clothes and has been in that trade for over 8 years. She sells her wares in the outlaying villages and in her community. Her objective is to buy bales direct from the wholesalers from Accra. This she hopes would impact positively on her business and family life with the KIVA loan.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Agusto Cesar

texts.en: My work is transporting people from one side of the city to the other. It is for that reason that I need to keep my vehicle in good conditions, in order to offer a better service. I also have a child in school, and with this business I pay for his education.

loans.use: Purchase of tires and car parts.

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en: Bernice is 33 years old and married with 3 children. She had no education but has benefited from the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN in October,2006. She is eager to put the skills acquired at the training to improve her business. She is looking forward to a KIVA loan to achieve this purpose. She wants to sell household items in her community.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Domitila

texts.en: I have been selling clothing for three years, and I need to enlarge a room in my house to be able to keep my product. I support my family with this work.

loans.use: To sell clothing and improve my home.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
Richard is married with 5 children; his children are 27, 25, 14, 8, and 5 years of age. When he was 15 years old, Ricardo began been selling ice cream and tostadas outside of his house. Later he sold toys and was successful in that business. His natural affinity for sales, his desire to overcome obstacles, and the need to move his family ahead have allowed Ricardo to set himself up in the sales of various items. He now works selling paper products and accessories wholesale, to businesses.

The hard sales work Ricardo does in order to improve his family's quality of life requires a considerable investment. For that reason he is applying for a loan of 925 dollars for the purchase of merchandise. He commits to repaying the loan in a period of 5 to 10 months. You can help Ricardo. Your collaboration will be of great service to this family, and they appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Ricardo es casado y tiene cinco hijos de 27, 25, 14, 8 y 5 años de edad, desde hace quince años empezó vendiendo afuera de su casa tostadas y helados, y después vendió juguetes y obtuvo buenos resultados. El gusto por las ventas, los deseos de superación y la necesidad de sacar adelante a su familia, le ha permitido a Ricardo incursionar en la venta de varios artículos, pero ahora se dedica a la venta de papelería y mercería en mayoreo para empresas.

El arduo trabajo de ventas que realiza Ricardo, para mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia, requiere de mayor inversión por lo que solicita de un préstamo de $ 925 dólares para la compra de mercancía, que se compromete a devolver en un plazo de 5 a 10 meses. Tú puedes ayudar a Ricardo, tu colaboración será de gran utilidad para esta familia, y agradecen tu apoyo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Marco Antonio

texts.en:
Mr. Marco Antonio started selling brooms, mops and aromatic solutions in 1980. He is married and has 5 children. He started his business as a form of personal growth and as a means to support his family. Marco began by selling door to door a few brooms he had been able to purchase with a lot of effort. Thanks to his hard work he now sells wholesale, as well, and provides products to local businesses. He now wants to buy land where he can manufacture and sell his own products.

To be able to fill his client orders and offer a good service to his clients, Marco is applying for a loan of $275, which will allow him to increase his inventory and his sales. You can be an important part of the growth of his business. He needs your support and sincerely appreciates your help.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Marco Antonio inició con L. venta D. escobas, trapeadores y aromatizantes desD. 1980, él es casado y tiene cinco hijos, empezó con su negocio como una forma D. superación personal y para obtener el sustento D. su familia. Marco comenzó vendiendo pocas escobas D. casa en casa, que con esfuerzo logró comprar, pero gracias a su arduo trabajo ahora pueD. vender también a mayoreo y surtir algunos negocios. Ahora quiere conseguir un terreno para poder elaborar él mismo sus productos y comercializarlo.

Para poder surtir los pedidos se sus clientes y ofrecer un buen servicio, el señor Marco solicita un préstamo por L. cantidad D. $ 275 dólares que le permitirá incrementar sus inventarios así como sus ventas. Tú puedes ser parte importante en el crecimiento D. su negocio, él necesita D. tu apoyo y agradece sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 42 years old and married with 2 children. She only has a basic eduction but has gone through KRABAN'S 'TEACH' learning sessions.She thus has the skills in managing such a facility if accorded one. With her shop at strategic location, she hopes to increase the range of products on her shelves.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: José Arturo

texts.en:
José Arturo is married with three small children. He and his family are originally from the town of Guachochi in the state of Chihuahua. José worked for five years in a carpenter's workshop, but he longed to start his own business, and decided to work on his own. In the beginning he had few tools, all manual. He was making decorative furniture, such as mirrors, frames, etc. He currently has his workshop in his house. Little by little he has been acquiring machinery and tools better suited to the manufacture of all types of furniture, as well as the installation of furniture.

José has worked very hard to achieve what he has achieved, but he needs an angular electric saw for the specialized manufacture of his furniture. He is applying for a loan of $475 to buy this tool. Be a part of the growth of this business. José needs your help and appreciates any support you are able to offer him.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

José Arturo es casado, y tiene tres pequeñas hijas, ellos son originarios de la localidad de Guachochi en el estado de Chihuahua. José trabajo durante cinco años en un taller de carpintería, pero tenia deseos de iniciar su propio negocio por lo que decidió independizarse, en un principio contaba con poca herramienta, solo manual y fabricaba muebles de ornato, como espejos, portarretratos, cuadros, etc. Actualmente tiene su taller en su casa, poco a poco ha ido adquiriendo maquinaria y herramienta mejor equipada para la elaboración de muebles de todo tipo, además de la fabricación también ofrece la instalación de éstos.

José ha trabajado muy duro para poder lograr lo que ahora tiene, pero necesita de una sierra angular eléctrica para la elaboración especializada de los muebles que fabrica, por lo que solicita de un crédito por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares. Forma parte del crecimiento de este negocio, José necesita de tu ayuda y agradece cualquier apoyo que puedas ofrecerle.

loans.use: Buy carpentry tools

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.en:
Francisco is married and has 4 children, who are 1, 3, 7 and 10 years old. He works selling tripe, pigs feet, barbeque and broths in a business he inherited from his father. His father started the business 18 years ago in their hometown: Saltillo, Coahuila. Francisco has had to work a lot to move his business ahead and to remain a favorite of his clients during so many years. He has been able to do so thanks to the support of his family. At the moment he needs a loan of $375, which he will use to buy materials which will allow him to provide a better service to his clients. He commits to repaying the loan in a period of 3 to 6 months.

Francisco has dedicated all of his life to this business, and wants to improve his working conditions in order to offer his family a better quality of life. You can become an important part of the growth of this business. Don't hesitate any longer; please decide to support him.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Francisco es casado y tiene cuatro hijos, de 1, 3, 7 y 10 años de edad. Él se dedica a la venta de menudo, barbacoa y caldos, negocio que le fue heredado de su padre quien lo inició hace 18 años, en la localidad de Saltillo, Coahuila, de donde son originarios. Francisco ha tenido que trabajar mucho para sacar adelante su negocio y permanecer por tanto tiempo en el gusto de sus clientes, pero lo ha conseguido gracias al apoyo de su familia. En estos momentos él necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 375 dólares que empleará en la compra de materiales que necesita para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, y se compromete a devolverlo en un lapso de 3 a 6 meses.

Francisco ha dedicado toda su vida a este negocio, y quiere mejorar las condiciones en las que trabaja para poder ofrecerle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. Tú puedes formar parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio, no lo dudes más y decídele a apoyarlo.

loans.use: Buy raw materials

loans.name: Juana Inés

texts.en:
Juana Inés is 48 years old. She is an enthusiastic, hardworking and responsible woman. She used to work as an employee in a business but she lost her job, and had to find a way to support her mother, who at her advanced age needs medical attention and medicines. That was when she decided to start her own business, selling groceries. This business allows her not only to earn the resources she needs to support the family, but also to spend more time with her mother. In 1995 she started her business in a vacant lot she reconditioned to serve as her store. Little by little she has continued to grow her business and with the help of an aunt she has been able to move it ahead.

Now Juana needs a loan of $750 to buy merchandise and make improvements to her store. She agrees to repay the loan in 5 to 10 months. She has confidence in people who help those who need it most, and she appreciates your help.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Juana Inés tiene 48 años de edad, es una mujer entusiasta, trabajadora y responsable, ella trabajaba como empleada en una empresa pero quedó desempleada y tenía a su cargo a su madre que es de edad avanzada y necesita de atención médica y medicinas. Entonces decidió iniciar su propio negocio y vender productos de abarrotes, este negocio le permitió, además de obtener los recursos necesarios para el sustento, pasar más tiempo al cuidado de su madre. En 1995 inició su negocio en un terreno baldío que fue acondicionando para poner su tienda. Poco a poco ha ido surtiendo su negocio y con ayuda de su tía han podido salir adelante.

Ahora Juana necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 750 dólares que utilizará para impulsar su negocio con la compra de mercancía y mejorar el aspecto de su local, mismo que esta dispuesta a devolver en un plazo de 5 a 10 meses. Ella confía en las personas que ayudan a quien más lo necesita y agradece tu apoyo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Juana Marina

texts.en:
Juana Marina is 52 years old. She has a 20 year old son who is currently studying medicine, and a 14 year old daughter who is in middle school. Juana is separated from her husband, who does not contribute toward the payment of the family's expenses. Although she has a job in the Health Center in her hometown of Tampico, Tamaulipas, her salary does not cover the expenses of the household and her children's education. Recognizing the necessity to earn a little extra income, she decided to open her own clinic five years ago in a neighborhood very close to her home. Little by little she has been expanding her clientele and earning the confidence of her patients.

At this time Juana needs a loan of $650 which she will use to buy a scale for weighing babies and a nebulizer, because she has lots of patients with respiratory problems. She needs your help to be able to offer better attention to her patients and to help her family. Please support her.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Juana Marina tiene 52 años, un hijo de 20 años de edad que se encuentra estudiando la carrera de medicina y una hija de 14 años que estudia la secundaria. Actualmente Juana se encuentra separada de su esposo, quien no contribuye con los gastos de su familia. Aunque tiene un empleo en el Centro de Salud en la ciudad de Tampico, Tamaulipas, de donde son originarios, su salario no es suficiente para los gastos del hogar y de la educación de sus hijos. Por la necesidad de tener un ingreso extra ella decidió abrir su consultorio, hace cinco años, en un local en una colonia popular cerca de su domicilio, poco a poco ha estado ganando clientes y se ha ganado la confianza de sus pacientes.

En estos momentos Juana necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 650 dólares que empleara en la compra de una báscula para pesar bebés y un nebulizador porque tiene muchos pacientes con problemas respiratorios. Ella necesita de tu ayuda para poder ofrecer una mejor atención a sus pacientes y ayudar a su familia, apóyala.

loans.use: Purchase of medical instruments

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 30 years and married with 2 children. She has a basic education with further training in dressmaking. However, she has gone into the sale of dairy products since the dressmaking industry is not encouraging. She managed to secure a used deep freezer to store the products. However, with the increase in electricity tariffs she is paying more. She intends to use a KIVA loan to buy a new freezer to reduce the tariffs and prolong the storage period.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Lonaix

texts.en:
Lonaix T. is the mother of three young children in a small community outside Trou-du-Nord, one of Haiti´s largest cities in the northeastern part of the country. Her business is selling household items in town. This loan will provide Lonaix with money to purchase supplies such as craft accessories, baskets, flowers, etc. She runs a successful business with the limited amount of materials she currently has, but needs this loan to support her children to provide them with basic necessities that are hard to come by in their semi-rural hometown.

NOTE: Lonaix T. and nine other micro-entrepreneurs are part of the Les Solidaires group - part of a Bank of Hope designed by Esperanza to create a social network and accountability system. Lonaix and every other member in her group will receive an equal share of this $1,200 loan to develop their own businesses to support their families. They also provide ongoing advice for each other and help one another make payments on their loans. This group-lending method has proven to be a highly effective way to ensure loan repayment and community support.

loans.use: Purchase craft accessories, baskets and garment material

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: I have been selling sweets and candies for 2 years. I need to replenish my inventory so that I can keep selling this month. With this business I help my family and children with their studies.

loans.use: To sell sweets, etc.

loans.name: Luz Maria

texts.en:
Luz Maria is 38 years old. She started selling purified water in 1995, helping an aunt. At the time she needed the income to support her son, since she was a single mother and had no one to help her. Later she met her current partner, Oscar; they have a 2 year old child. When they moved to a new home, Luz continued in the purified water business. Because she is in a new neighborhood she has had excellent demand and has been able to grow her business through the distribution of her product.

At the moment Luz Maria needs a loan of $475, which she will use to buy plastic bottles for her water. She is expanding her delivery area and needs this investment. She will repay the loan in 4 to 8 months. Support Luz Maria in the growth of her business. She needs your help and she sincerely appreciates it.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Luz Maria tiene 38 años de edad e inició con la venta de agua purificada desde 1995 ayudándole a una tía, por la necesidad que tenía de obtener los recursos para el sustento de su hijo, en ese entonces era madre soltera y no tenía quien le ayudara. Después conoció a Oscar, su actual pareja, y tienen un pequeño hijo de 2 años. Se cambiaron de domicilio y Luz continuó con el negocio del agua purificada, por ser una colonia nueva, han tenido mucha demanda y ha visto la oportunidad de hacer crecer su negocio mediante la distribución de su producto.

En estos momentos Luz Maria necesita de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 475 dólares que empleará en la compra de botellones que utiliza para la venta del agua, porque está ampliado la zona de reparto y requiere de esta inversión, misma que esta dispuesta a regresar en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. Apoya a Luz en el crecimiento de su negocio, ella necesita de tu ayuda y te lo agradece sinceramente.

loans.use: Buy plastic bottles

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Lizzie is 36 years old and married with 4 children who are in school. She had no formal education but has fought against all odds to get her children well educated. Towards this she has decided not to give birth anymore. Her resolve was given a boost with the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN in October 2006. She prepares kenkey and fried fish for sale in her community. She would like a KIVA loan to improve the conditions under which she serves her customers.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Glenda Yamileth

texts.en: I have been selling seasonings for cooking for 3 years. I generally purchase large quantities so that I can package and sell them individually to neighbors and markets.

loans.use: To sell cooking seasonings.

loans.name: Hortencia

texts.en: I have been selling women’s beauty products (cosmetics, shampoo and conditioner) for 2 years. I also sell candy in my home. My clients are neighbors and women who work in offices. With the income I earn, I support my family and provide for my children’s education.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics (creams, eye shadows, shampoo, conditioner, etc.)

loans.name: Iris Nohemy

texts.en: I have been selling common food products for three years. With the income I earn I support my family and children.

loans.use: Purchase of bread, beverages, milk, eggs, sugar, churros, etc.

loans.name: Luz Areli

texts.en: My business is making and packaging tortillas, and I have been doing so for 3 years. I distribute them in my community, and I support my family with the income I earn.

loans.use: Purchase of corn and packaging for tortillas.

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Clara has lived around Baba for her entire life. She has a small piece of land where she plants rice, corn, plantains and cacao. She also has a small business in the small town of Baba, where she sells juice, tortillas and snacks. She is applying for the loan because she wants to buy pigs that she will eventually sell as a secondary source of income. She will also invest in her land to produce rice. She has twins who are currently living in Guayaquil because they want to go to school. Clara has been trying to help them study but is having a hard time paying for their school and living expenses. Clara’s dream is to help her two sons graduate as professionals from a good school in the large city.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their land and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive land that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The land in Baba is very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm, they first must prepare the land by removing weed, plowing and leveling it. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the land for rice production. After appropriately preparing the land, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial support, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers), there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Invest in raising pigs

loans.name: Maria Glenda

texts.en: My business is the sale of bread, rice, frijoles, sugar, etc. to my neighbors. I have been doing so for 2 years. With the income I bring in I help cover my family’s expenses, education and medications.

loans.use: Purchase of bread, churros, rice, frijoles, condiments, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Nolvia Liceth

texts.en: My business is the sale of seasonings for all types of food preparation, and I have been doing so for two and a half years. I use my income for my family and education.

loans.use: Purchase of cooking seasonings.

loans.name: Santo Teofila

texts.en: My business is the sale of food like frijoles, eggs, bananas, meat, etc., and I have been doing so for 3 years. With this business I am able to help feed my children and provide them with an education.

loans.use: Purchase of food, i.e. frijoles, rice, coffee, eggs, bananas and dairy products.

loans.name: Glenda Elizabeth

texts.en: For two years my business has been the sale of used clothing in good condition since many people in my community cannot go to a store to buy new clothes due to their low income. In addition, I support my family with my earnings.

loans.use: To buy and sell second-hand clothing in good condition.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel is 37 years old, married, and has two sons of 8 and 10 years of age. He earns a living by repairing computers, yet he works only on occasions/scarcely and doesn't count his earnings towards heping pay for home expenses. His wife studied to be a stylist and since he does not have a full time position, she decided to open her own shop approximately 10 years ago. She learned her trade and together they initiated this business in their living room. Little by little their business has grown and they have gained clients, and today they already have an air conditioned space in the front of their house.

Manuel and his wife have worked very hard to provide a good service for their clients, but today they are asking for a loan of $650 which would allow them to buy accessories and beauty products necessary for business expansion, as well as improve their business' look. They anticipate repaying this loan within a 5 to 10 month period. This loan will be an important factor in the expansion of this business, and in helping his family, and they appreciate your support.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Manuel tiene 37 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos, de 8 y de 10 años. Él trabajaba reparando computadoras, pero en ocasiones el trabajo escaseaba y no contaban con los recursos para solventar los gastos del hogar. Su esposa estudio para estilista y como él no tenía un trabajo fijo, decidieron abrir su propio negocio hace 10 años, él aprendió el oficio y juntos iniciaron en la sala de su casa, poco a poco han ido creciendo y ganando clientes, ahora ya tiene un local acondicionado en el frente de su casa.

Manuel y su esposa han trabajado mucho para poder brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes y conservar su preferencia, pero ahora solicitan un crédito por la cantidad de $ 650 dólares que emplearan para la compra de accesorios y artículos de belleza que necesitan para trabajar, así como la realización de mejoras del local, que esta dispuesto a regresar en un lapso de 5 a 10 meses. Se parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio, y ayuda a esta familia, ellos agradecen tu apoyo.

loans.use: Acquisition of accessories and beauty products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Plant rice and feed livestock

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara is a very hard worker with a large desire for X. She has four sons. At the age of 14 she began to sell milk because her parents did not make enough to support her going to secondary school. Today she is married and continues her business in order to contribute for her sons' education. Her business has expanded little by little, as well as her clients.

Sara is an enterprising woman who desires to expand her business, and is asking today for a loan of $650. She will use this loan to buy millk products from Ozuluama and Veracruz, with the aim of increasing sales and having a greater benefit. Sara needs your support and sincerely appreciate whatever help you can provide her.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Sara es muy trabajadora y con grandes deseos de superación, ella tiene cuatro hijos. Desde que tenía 14 años comenzó con la venta de lácteos porque sus padres no contaban con los recursos suficientes para que ella pudiera asistir a la secundaria. Ahora ella está casada y continuó con el negocio para contribuir al gasto familiar y la educación de sus hijos. Su negocio ha ido creciendo poco a poco, así como sus clientes.

Sara es una mujer emprendedora que desea ver crecer su negocio, ahora requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 650 dólares que utilizará para la compra de productos lácteos que provienen de Ozuluama, Veracruz, con la finalidad de incrementar las ventas y obtener un mayor beneficio. Sara necesita de tu apoyo y agradece sinceramente cualquier ayuda que puedas darle.

loans.use: Buy perishable goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Cultivate rice

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Joncilia

texts.en:
Joncilia (pictured with one of her daughters who helps run her clothing store) raises seven children out of her thatched home outside Trou-du-Nord in north western Haiti. To support her large family, she has opened up two stores outside her house, situated along a small river heavily frequented by her neighbours. Joncilia runs a small candy stand as well as a clothing store. This loan will allow Joniclia to pay for transportation to the larger markets near the Dominican boarder and have capital to purchase a larger amount of clothes so she will not have to travel as frequently to replenish her inventory. She is hard-working and a well-respected member of her town. Joncilia has established a good business plan and clientele base but needs additional funding to make her businesses more self-sustainable while still supporting her seven children and saving for improving their home and their future.

NOTE: Jonicilia and four other micro-entrepreneurs in her community have formed a solidarity group to receive equal shares of $400 of this $1200 loan to develop their respective businesses. They have each gone through Esperanza´s business training program and proven to be responsible leaders of their household and community. They have each been evaluated and Esperanza personnel have determined that they are in the greatest need for micro-credit services in order to provide the basic necessities for their children and support the community.

loans.use: Purchase pants, shirts, dresses, hats in bulk; pay for transportation to the markets; increase capital for investment and savings

loans.name: Jose Eduardo

texts.en:
Mr. Eduardo D. has been in business for 6 months. "I need to buy a little bit of everything. There are things that my clients ask me for that I don't have, so they go somewhere else to buy them. I would like to have a wider selection of products since the location of my business is very good for sales. If I am able to purchase all the products that I need, my sales will increase and therefore, I''l have more income. I am requesting $1,000 to invest in my office supply and gift store business."

Translated from Spanish by Lighthouse Translations, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor José Eduardo D. tiene su negocio desde hace 6 meses. "Necesito comprar un poco de todo, hay cosas que mis clientes me piden y no las tengo en existencia, así que se van a comprarlas a otra parte, me gustaría poder tener variedad en mis productos, el lugar en donde estoy ubicado es muy bueno para las ventas si logro comprar todo lo que me hace falta tendré mas venta y por lo tanto mas ingresos Solicito $1,000.00 dlls para invertir en la tienda de papelería y regalos.

loans.use:
Invest in an Office Supply and Gift store busines

Invertir en el negocio de Papeleria y Regalos

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rice Cultivation

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase products from wholesalers

payments.comment: PAGO DE CENTRO AGRÍCOLA DE BABA

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Armando cultivates rice, watermelons, corn and soy beans on his land. He has been living in this area for about forty years. He lives with his wife and three of his sons who help him with the farming. He also lives with 4 grandchildren in his small home. He hopes to invest the loan in the preparation of his land for production and to purchase fertilizer. He is trying to save money in order to increase the size of his home for his family.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive land that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large mulitnational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by the small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The land in Baba is very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soy beans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Baba

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm, they first must prepare the land by removing weed, plowing and leveling it. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the land for rice production. After appropriately preparing the land, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial support, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers), there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mrs. Lucy and her husband have a store for supplying lubricants (oils for motors, brake and clutch fluid) for vehicles. They live in the city of El Alto on Litoral Avenue. Their store is located in their house. The have two minor children dependent on them, making this work their only source of income for maintaining the family. She works independently, and this loan is intended for the purchase of merchandise (lubricants) for moving into the business of providing for public and private transport of the city. This will be her ninth loan with Impro, and her past history makes her a number 2 client, which is to say, with a good record of paying her obligations. Her credit history should permit her to obtain this credit since she has experience in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Dwight Davis, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Lucy y su esposo tienen una tienda de servicio de Lubricantes (Aceites para motor, freno y embrague) para vehículos. Viven en la Ciudad de El Alto Av. Litoral, su tienda se encuentra ubicada en su mismo domicilio. Tiene dos hijos menores de edad y bajo su dependencia, siendo este trabajo su única fuente de ingresos para la manutención de su familia. La Sra.Lucy trabaja independientemente y el crédito esta orientado a la compra de mercadería (lubricantes), para su comercialización a transportistas públicos y particulares de la ciudad de El Alto. Es su noveno crédito en Impro, su historial en nuestra institución califica como cliente 2, es decir con buen cumplimiento de pago de su obligación. Sus antecedentes crediticios le permiten acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en su negocio.

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.en:
Luis has a very small but productive rice farm. He has been living on these lands for about thirty years with his wife and family. He has raised all 8 of children with the rice production from his farm. He lives with four of his grandchildren and works hard to educate them. He will invest in fertilizer and seeds for the upcoming season. He hopes to one day fix his house and have enough saved up to rest and retire. At the moment he is still in good spirits to work and provide for his family.

PAGO DE CENTRO AGRICOLA DE BABA

loans.name: Misael Albino

texts.en:
Albino produces rice, corn, soy beans, mango and plantains. He is extremely happy to have such a productive land. He also has a few cows, chickens, pigs ,and ducks, but arecomplimentary sources of income. He makes ends meet with the profits he makes from rice production. In his home he lives with his wife, kids, some grandchildren and his mother. He will invest the loan in preparing his lands and in fertilizer. He hopes with the investments he will have more productivity from the land and to fix the roof of his home.

loans.name: Maximo

texts.en:
Maximo has been living in Baba his entire life. He has a primary education, and is a very hard worker. Through his farming he has been able to raise six children. He lives with his wife Marcia, a son and a daughter. They help him plant rice, plantains, bananas, and corn. He also raises some chickens, pigs, and cows. He hopes he can invest in a chicken coop so he can establish a business. He is optimistic about the loan because chicken sales provide a good secondary source of income in case of emergencies. With the extra profits he hopes to help pay for one of his grandchildren's university studies.

texts.en:
Elisa has a small plot of land that she bought about 30 years ago. She lives on the land with her son and his family of three children. They primarily plant rice, but also raise chickens and pigs as a secondary source of income. She hopes to invest the money in making her production greater by buying fertilizer. With her extra income she also wants to help her grandchildren go to school and hopefully make more investments in her land.

loans.name: Flavio

texts.en:
Flavio has land mainly produces rice. He uses the land to feed his three children ages 17, 13 and 11. He and his wife work in the fields everyday hoping to have a good crop yield. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides, and will make a small investment in land preparation. He was born and raised in Baba, but he hopes his children can gain an education and move to a bigger city. His main short term goal is to make all the lands he owns productive, as certain sectors have not been prepared for farming.

In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soy beans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Guido

texts.en:
Guido produces rice and corn on lands given to him by his father, with also some small production of plantains. He lives with his brother who he works in the fields with. He will invest the loan to plant for the next cycle. He will prepare the lands and also buy fertilizer and seeds. Although he does not have children, he is still very family oriented. He is very close to his mother, father and brother. He hopes he can fix the lands so they can be productive for years to come. He is also hoping to start a family of his own in the near future.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Juan lives with his youngest son who is 16. Together they work their fields to plant and cultivate rice and corn. Juan is 65, but is still a very hard worker who wants to make sure he leaves his family with fertile lands. His wife passed away several years ago and he has three kids total. He hopes with the loan he make investments in preparing the fields and purchasing fertilizer.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose owns a small clothing store. He has also has a weekend market stand set up in the town in Baba. He does well selling clothing because of his low prices. He travels into Guayaquil (the larger city) to buy their clothing from wholesalers at reasonable prices. He is hoping to invest the loan in buying more products so he can offer better variety at cheaper prices.

loans.name: Gonzalo

texts.en:
Gonzalo has a farm where he grows rice and corn. He lives with his wife and a son on their land and they all work on together. He admits he once was not on the right path as he drank excessively. He is now a religious man after suffering an accident where he lost an eye. He hopes to invest his money in fertilizer and seeds for the fields. He is a very hard worker who saves in order to one day send his son to college.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor has been living on his farm for 28 years. He plants rice and also has a small plot for cacao production. He lives with his wife, two sons, and granddaughter. He and his sons work the lands in order to feed the family. He will invest the loan to plant a new plot of rice. He will have to help his sons with the fertilizer and seeds because he is no longer able to work the fields himself. After retrieving the crop Victor does commercialize them using his years of experience in the sector.

texts.en:
Carlos lives with his wife and three children, ages 20, 18 and 15. His sons produce rice on the land with Carlos. The family relies completely on rice production in order to survive. With the loan he will buy seeds, fertilizer, and pesticides and hopes to fix his home. He will also make the lands as productive as possible so his children will be able to produce from them in the future.

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan has a store in the small town of Baba where he sells all kinds of snacks and beverages. He also makes different types of fast foods to sell to the people of the town. This loan will allow him to fix up his store. He is hoping to make the storefront more attractive to clients by putting in a gate and also by buying a glass display case. He used to be a farm worker, but decided to move to town after suffering through a bad crop year. He still has some land with some family members, but he would prefer to invest the money in his small store.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis lives on his farm with his wife and four children. He still has three children who are in school. He supports his family with the income from rice farming on his small, but productive farm. With the loan he receives, he hopes that he can buy machinery that will help him prepare the land he works on. His biggest goal is to be able to buy land of his own because he currently rents the land, and the farm he works on. He hopes he can acquire his own property to hand down to his children one day.

loans.name: Evaristo

texts.en:
Evaristo has been working on his farm for about 8 years. He lives with his wife and his 3 daughters, ages 10, 3 and 3 months. He relies completely on rice farming to feed his family, as his land is only productive for this activity. He was born and raised in Baba and learned to farm rice from his father. He wants to make some improvements to his home such as fixing the roof, which has a bad leak. He also wants to save for his daughters' education.

loans.name: Aroldo

texts.en:
Aroldo was born and raised in Baba, and has been farming rice his entire life. He lives with one of his daughters and her family. He works the land with the help of his sons who share in profits from the production. He has been living on the land for more than 60 years. He hopes that he will be able to buy fertilizer and seeds with the loan. He also wants to rent a tractor to work the land so it will be more productive.

The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Farm Rice

payments.comment: This adjustment was made to compensate for an error with the previous payment posted.

loans.name: Jocqueson

texts.en:
Jocqueson is an artisan who makes large baskets and bins made of bamboo strips woven together. He creates different shapes and sizes, makes designs with how he weaves the threads and paints each craft different colors. Jocqueson takes his two children to school then heads off to a mission near their house where he is allotted a small room that serves as his workshop. This loan will allow him the funds to expand his business, which is very small and lacks capital for materials, yet is showing promise for large growth in the marketplace. He sells his products in large outdoor markets in Trou-du-Nord and Cap-Haitien - two densely populated urban areas in the northeast of Haiti.

NOTE: Jocqueson is the leader of his solidarity group called Fraternite. He and his business represent the nine other members of Fraternite, who each will receive a share of this $1,200 loan to fund their respective businesses. As members of a solidarity group, Jocqueson and the other 9 micro-entrepreneurs have gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have proven to be committed to their business to provide for their family. If a member of the group is unable to make a payment, the other members are responsible for making up the difference and helping the person to improve. This group-lending method creates a social support network within the community as well as an accountability system to ensure that not only are loans paid back on time, but that the loan capital is invested in developing their business and providing for the basic necessities of their families.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials, paint, cover transportation costs, increase capital and savings to expand business

loans.name: Ivonne

texts.en:
Ivonne sells soap and wax candles that she has made, along with various snacks to support her two young sons. There is no electricity in the semi-rural village where Ivonne sells her products. There is a large market for candles that are used by practically everyone at night to light the rooms in their homes or light their way on the streets. The soaps she sells are in high demand as well, whether for bathing, doing laundry or the dishes. This loan will allow her to purchase large amounts of both products to expand her inventory, allow her to make fewer trips to the larger markets further away and will give her the capital she needs to invest in a stable place of business. Ivonne has been successful despite walking the crowded streets selling her wares out of a cardboard box. With this loan, her inventory will be too large to carry around and she will construct a proper stand to set up her business. Ivonne has a very soft and approachable manner that helps her gain steady clients as well as develop new ones.

NOTE: Ivonne is a member of the Soleil Brillant solidarity group. She and her business represent 9 other micro-entrepreneurs who are members of the same solidarity group. Each members will receive a share of this $1,200 loan to develop their respective businesses. The cost of living in Haiti is such that Esperanza is able to fund 10 entrepreneurs who must make each payment together. If one person is unable to pay, the other members must make up the difference before any payment will be excepted. The community of 10 entrepreneurs have gone through Esperanza´s business training courses and have demonstrated their commitment and aptitude for receiving a loan to expand their business. Ivonne and the other members are responsible for working with one another as a social support network throughout the loan repayment and business development processes.

loans.use: Purchase soaps and wax in bulk as well as materials for constructing a business stand

loans.name: Luiciano

texts.en:
Luiciano was born and raised in Baba, Ecuador. He has worked in rice production since he was young, after learning from his father. He bought his land about 15 years ago. He depends on his rice production to feed and educate his two children who are 6 and 7 years old. He lives with his wife, children, his father and a sister. They all work together in the fields in order to cultivate rice. He will use the loan to invest in seeds, fertilizer and pesticides. He hopes he can improve his home and save for the future of his children.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

loans.name: Walter

texts.en:
Walter is a plantain farmer from Baba. His land is better for plantain production because of the water and the soil. He also produces some rice, but only as a secondary source of income. Walter has six children, three of which live at home with him. Walter Jr. is pictured with him. He will use the loan for rice farming. His main goal for the future is to make his lands more productive because currently, they are not level and they need work.

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Alvina plants rice and corn on her farm. She lives on the land with her husband and three children. She was born in Baba and has been involved in rice production for her entire life. She hopes to invest the loan in fertilizer and the rental of machinery to work the lands. She is hoping that, with the profits, she can finish constructing her home which was left incomplete. She works her part of the land on her own, with little help from her husband who has a separate plot that he rents. She works primarily to educate and feed her children.

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en:
Miss Hoa is a poor lady, 37 years old. Her husband died ago 12 years. Miss Hoa has two children, 14 and 12. Miss Hoa is supporting both her children who are going to school.

She dosesn’t have any land for cultivation so selling folded rice pancakes is important for her family as additional income. This earns about $2/person/month, and their average income is $11/person/month. Now Miss Hoa asks to borrow a loan of $75 for her rice pancake business.

loans.use: Selling folded rice pancakes

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.en:
Mr. Mejia has been in business for 3 years operating an office supply store. During this time, he has been able to innovate his business by also adding an Internet cafe. Because of this growth, his computer equipment is not sufficient. "I am in great need of buying more computers since the number of clients exceeds the number of existing computers. $1,200 would be enough to purchase two additional computers."

Translated from Spanish by Lighthouse Translations, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. M. lleva 3 años con su papelería, en este lapso ha logrado innovar el tipo de mercado y de una simple papelería a transformado su negocio en un ciber, por ello el equipo con el que cuenta no es suficiente. "Hoy tengo una gran necesidad de comprar computadoras ya que el numero de mis clientes rebasa la cantidad de computadoras existentes, $1,200.00 dlls será suficiente para comprar dos equipos.

loans.use:
To purchase additional computers

Compra de computadoras

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa lives with her husband and has five children. Her children are all grown up but two still live with her. She is also caring for a close family friend who has a brain tumor, but cannot afford medical care. With her loan she will invest in her rice production. As complimentary crops she farms cacao, mangoes and corn. She hopes that, with the loan, she will be able to invest in her land, making the soil more productive. She also wants to finish a section of her home which is still under construction.
